author: Karen Halabi
title: The best way to spend 48 hours in historic Kyoto in Japan
text:
KYOTO is Japan’s cultural and cuisine heart and a city that has largely escaped the modernisation of other Japanese cities such as Tokyo.
Kyoto embodies “wabi-sabi” (the Japanese art of finding beauty in the natural, the authentic and the traditional) and the spirit of omotenashi (Japanese hospitality). Preserving its traditional culture, Kyoto is a place you can catch a glimpse into Japan’s past. It’s a little bit of how the world was … and don’t we love it. Here’s how to spend 48 hours in historic Kyoto .
WONDROUS ATTRACTIONS YOU HAVE NEVER HEARD OF
THE TOP SPOT FOR A FAMILY TRIP
Maiko dancers perform in Kyoto. Picture: Karen Halabi Source: Supplied
8am Arrive at Kansai International Airport; head to Arashiyama, on the western outskirts of Kyoto and a half-hour from the centre.
9am Check in to the Hoshinoya, a ryokan-style “hotel” with tatami rooms and sliding shoji panels, which sits by the Oigawa river in Arashiyama, the most tranquil setting in Kyoto. A private boat whisks you upriver to this picturesque retreat, a beautiful hideaway set in a forest. See global.hoshinoresort.com/hoshinoya_kyoto
10am Head nearby to the breathtakingly beautiful Bamboo Forest — also in Arashiyama district. Rows and rows of soaring bamboo in a grove create an amazingly ethereal, otherworldly effect. Arashiyama is a nationally designated Historic Site and “Place of Scenic Beauty”. Take a walk through the cool green forest and soak up the air.
A proud rickshaw driver with his conveyance. Picture: Karen Halabi Source: Supplied
Meet a geisha girl or three in Kyoto. Picture: Karen Halabi Source: Supplied
11am Afterwards, step back in time by taking a ride through Arashiyama in a rickshaw — they are pulled by athletic young men in tights who run on foot wearing split toe sock-shoes. Great views all around.
Noon Visit Kodai-ji Zen, a national heritage temple. Stroll through the famous Japanese gardens designed by Enshu Kobori.
Learn how to make Japanese green matcha tea the traditional way at Iho-an (The Cottage of Lingering Fragrances) a tea ceremony house in the temple grounds. Tea ceremonies run regularly throughout the day. See kodaiji.com
Abamboo grove at Arashiyama, a district on the outskirts of Kyoto. Picture: Karen Halabi Source: Supplied
2pm For lunch enjoy genuine obanzai — traditional Kyoto cuisine — during an obanzai kaiseki lunch at Mukadeya, a restored traditional house in central Kyoto. Kaiseki is a traditional multi-course meal made up of many small seasonal dishes; obanzai means Kyoto-style. The emphasis is on the aesthetic presentation of local delicacies and seasonal foods such as river fish, dried tofu and mountain vegetables in winter, arranged on carefully chosen ceramic or lacquer dishes that echo the time of year. Mukadeya, 381 Mukadeya-cho in Nakagyo-ku. See r.gnavi.co.jp/k153600/lang/en
3pm Walk up to Kiyomizu-dera Temple on top of a hill overlooking Kyoto to see one of Kyoto’s UNESCO world heritage treasures. Kiyomizu-dera is a historic temple that was established even before Kyoto became the capital of Japan in 794. It is registered on the UNESCO World Cultural Heritage List as one of the Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto. Here meet a Japanese monk and learn about Zen from a Zen master. See kiyomizudera.or.jp/
4pm From the temple, stroll downhill along Ninen-zaka and Sannen-zaka, both fascinating historic steep narrow shopping lanes with traditional wooden shops. Buy a kimono, handpainted umbrella, Japanese clogs, handmade paper or some local sweets. The Higashiyama shopping district is one of the city’s best-preserved historic districts.
A tea ceremony that cannot be missed. Picture: Karen Halabi Source: Supplied
5pm Stop en route to take afternoon tea in a traditional teashop, Kasagiya. 349 Masuya cho, Kodai-ji, Higashiyama-ku. Taste the numerous varieties including sencha, matcha and gyokuro and buy some to take home.
While you’re there, discover Japanese toilet humour: try out a spouting, spraying, warming Japanese toilet: you’ll find them in most restaurants, teashops and hotels and soon you will really look forward to ablution time.
7pm Visit Kangaan, a Zen Buddhist temple in the city, and try traditional vegetarian dishes (known as fucha ryori) all prepared by the monks. Be prepared for a lot of “mock” food that looks like meat but isn’t. See kangaan.jp
8pm Not up for vegetarian food? Head back to eat at your ryokan. The Hoshinoya has a special Michelin star restaurant serving exquisite 12-course feasts. This is modern kaiseki at its best.
10.30pm Fall asleep in your bed on the floor looking out at the river.
DAY 2
9am Visit Nishiki Ichiba, a 400-year-old covered food market known as the “Kitchen of Kyoto”, and discover 100 varieties of dried fish and tofu. kyoto-nishiki.or.jp
Watch Hina ceremonial dolls being made. Picture: Karen Halabi Source: Supplied
10am Watch Hina ceremonial dolls being made by a master craftsman at the Ando Japanese Traditional Doll Shop, a doll factory and traditional craftsmen’s workshop that makes dolls for the Imperial Palace. See ando-doll.com
Noon Relive Kyoto’s traditional lifestyle in a Kyo-machiya (traditional Kyoto townhouse). At Iori, learn Ikebana, the Japanese art of flower arranging (ikenaba). Chabana literally means “tea flowers” and is just another form of Japanese omotenashi (the art of service).
Beautiful smells abound at the Nishiki market. Picture: Karen Halabi Source: Supplied
1pm Don a kimono and sit on the floor for a kaiseki meal, the most refined dining experience in Kyoto. Kaiseki cuisine is a multi-course banquet of miniature dishes that look like mini artworks. Originally intended to be enjoyed with the tea ceremony, kaiseki-ryori is the ultimate Japanese cuisine and probably where modern cuisine’s obsession with presentation and plating began. Sit on a cushion on the floor and enjoy your “food as art” as beautiful women in kimonos bring to your table exquisite miniature artistic morsels presented on a tray or in a lacquerware box.
3pm Lose your “mind”: Visit Ryoanji Temple with its world famous UNESCO heritage-listed “dry landscape” Japanese garden. Afterwards relax in the temple’s Zen garden and meditate on its Zen rocks set into white gravel that’s raked into hypnotic swirling patterns. See ryoanji.jp/
5pm Tea time; well it’s Kyoto, so find the nearest teahouse to enjoy a cuppa. By now you’re a connoisseur of the leaf.
7.30pm At Gion Hatanaka a “performance restaurant” in the historic Gion district, watch a Maiko performance by junior geishas in training. Then dress up like a Maiko and be shown how to dance the Maiko way. Lots of fun and guaranteed to have you in stitches. See kyoto-maiko.jp
10pm That night head back to stay at your machiya, Iori. See kyoto-machiya.com/eng
DAY 3
9am Leave traditional Kyoto and head to modern Tokyo on the bullet train. Kyoto station itself is an amazing shopping and eating hub so take the opportunity to look around and pick up a bargain or two.
